refsect1.title: Description
refsect1.para: A unit configuration file whose name ends in .device encodes information about a device unit as exposed in the sysfs/udev7 device tree. This may be used to define dependencies between devices and other units.

This unit type has no specific options. See systemd.unit5 for the common options of all unit configuration files. The common configuration items are configured in the generic [Unit] and [Install] sections. Device specific options are supported in the [Device] section .

systemd will dynamically create device units for all kernel devices that are marked with the systemd udev tag (by default all block and network devices, and a few others). Note that if systemd-udevd.service is not running, no device units will be available (for example in a typical container).

Device units are named after the /sys/ and /dev/ paths they control. Example: the device /dev/sda5 is exposed in systemd as dev-sda5.device. For details about the escaping logic used to convert a file system path to a unit name see systemd.unit5.
To tag a udev device, use TAG+="systemd" in the udev rules file, see udev7 for details.
Device units will be reloaded by systemd whenever the corresponding device generates a changed event. Other units can use ReloadPropagatedFrom= to react to that event.

refsect2.title: Implicit Dependencies
refsect2.para: Many unit types automatically acquire dependencies on device units of devices they require. For example, .socket unit acquire dependencies on the device units of the network interface specified in BindToDevice=. Similar, swap and mount units acquire dependencies on the units encapsulating their backing block devices.

refsect2.title: Default Dependencies
refsect2.para: There are no default dependencies for device units.

refsect1.title: The udev Database
refsect1.para: Unit settings of device units may either be configured via unit files, or directly from the udev database. The following udev device properties are understood by the service manager:

listitem.para: Adds dependencies of type Wants= from the device unit to the specified units. SYSTEMD_WANTS= is read by the system service manager, SYSTEMD_USER_WANTS= by user service manager instances. These properties may be used to activate arbitrary units when a specific device becomes available.

Note that this and the other udev device properties are not taken into account unless the device is tagged with the systemd tag in the udev database, because otherwise the device is not exposed as a systemd unit (see above).

Note that systemd will only act on Wants= dependencies when a device first becomes active. It will not act on them if they are added to devices that are already active. Use SYSTEMD_READY= (see below) to configure when a udev device shall be considered active, and thus when to trigger the dependencies.

The specified property value should be a space-separated list of valid unit names. If a unit template name is specified (that is, a unit name containing an @ character indicating a unit name to use for multiple instantiation, but with an empty instance name following the @), it will be automatically instantiated by the device's sysfs path (that is: the path is escaped and inserted as instance name into the template unit name). This is useful in order to instantiate a specific template unit once for each device that appears and matches specific properties.
Adds an additional alias name to the device unit. This must be an absolute path that is automatically transformed into a unit name. (See above.)

If set to 0, systemd will consider this device unplugged even if it shows up in the udev tree. If this property is unset or set to 1, the device will be considered plugged if it is visible in the udev tree.

This option is useful for devices that initially show up in an uninitialized state in the tree, and for which a changed event is generated the moment they are fully set up. Note that SYSTEMD_WANTS= (see above) is not acted on as long as SYSTEMD_READY=0 is set for a device.
If set, this property is used as description string for the device unit.

refsect1.title: Options
refsect1.para: Device unit files may include [Device], [Unit] and [Install] sections. [Device] section includes device specific properties. [Unit] and [Install] sections are described in systemd.unit5.

listitem.para: Takes a boolean argument that is not assigned by default. The user has to explicitly enable IOCostQOSEnabled= in order to use io.cost.qos. If yes the io.cost.qos parameters are enabled. If no all other IOCostQOS fields are ignored. This controls the first field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Takes the special options auto and user. No options will be applied if unspecified, hence this does not have a default value. If auto, IOCostQOSRPercentile=, IOCostQOSRLat=, IOCostQOSWPercentile=, IOCostQOSRLat=, IOCostQOSWPercentile=, IOCostQOSWLat=, IOCostQOSMin=, and IOCostQOSMax= are all ignored. If user io.cost.qos parameters are controlled by the user and the properties listed for io.cost.qos will be applied. This controls the second field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Configure io.cost.qos read latency percentile. Value between 0.00% and 100.00% inclusive accurate to two decimal places. Defaults to 0.00%. This controls the third field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Configure io.cost.qos read latency threshold in milliseconds. Value between 0 and UINT32_MAX. Defaults to 0. The device is considered saturated if the 95th percentile of read completion latencies is above this threshold. This controls the fourth field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Configure io.cost.qos write latency percentile. Value between 0.00% and 100.00% accurate to two decimal places. Defaults to 0.00%. This controls the fifth field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Configure io.cost.qos write latency threshold in milliseconds. Value between 0 and UINT32_MAX. Defaults to 0. The device is considered saturated if the 95th percentile of write completion latencies is above this threshold. This controls the sixth field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Configure io.cost.qos min scaling percentage. Value between 1.00 and 10000.00 inclusive accurate to two decimal places and must be less than or equal to IOCostQOSMax=. Defaults to 1.00. Note that this field requires two digits after the decimal point. This value is clamped to the range supported by the kernel. Controller will adjust the overall IO rate between min and max percentiles based on internal device saturation state. This controls the seventh field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Configure io.cost.qos max scaling percentage. Value between 1.00 and 10000.00 accurate to two decimal places and must be greater than or equal to IOCostQOSMin=. Defaults to 1.00. Note that this field requires two digits after the decimal point. This value is clamped to the range supported by the kernel. Controller will adjust the overall IO rate between min and max percentiles based on internal device saturation state. This controls the eigth field of io.cost.qos control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Takes the special options auto and user. No options will be applied if unspecified, hence this does not have a default value. If auto, IOCostModelRbps=, IOCostModelRSeqIops=, IOCostModelRRandIops=, IOCostModelWbps=, IOCostModelWSeqIops=, and IOCostModelWRandIops= are all ignored. If user, io.cost.model parameters are controlled by the user and the properties listed for io.cost.model will be applied. This controls the first field of io.cost.model control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Maximum sequential read IO throughput in bytes per second. Value between 0 and UINT64_MAX. Defaults to 0. This controls the third field of io.cost.model control group attribute. Note that the second field is model, which is set to linear. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Maximum sequential read IOs per second. Value between 0 and UINT64_MAX. Defaults to 0. This controls the fourth field of io.cost.model control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Maximum random read IOs per second. Value between 0 and UINT64_MAX. Defaults to 0. This controls the fifth field of io.cost.model control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Maximum sequential write IO throughput in bytes per second. Value between 0 and UINT64_MAX. Defaults to 0. This controls the sixth field of io.cost.model control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Maximum sequential write IOs per second. Value between 0 and UINT64_MAX. Defaults to 0. This controls the seventh field of io.cost.model control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files

Maximum random write IOs per second. Value between 0 and UINT64_MAX. Defaults to 0. This controls the eighth field of io.cost.model control group attribute. For details about these control group attributes, see IO Interface Files
